comments.body:
correct me if i'm wrong,
the current (and even previous) code vulnerable to a case where one of the hash fields is completely missing from the result.
and we solve that by having another test that checks that each of the fields exists at least once.
is that right?

In the original code, if the proportion of one is particularly high or low, the test will fail, but there are times when it makes sense.
The original approach only simulates the case of a normal distribution, and the probability of failure is not known with certainty.
The current approach looks at the distribution from a global perspective, which is more reasonable.

diffHunk:

    set x2_value 0
    set p [expr [llength $res] / [dict size $mydict]]
    foreach key [dict keys $mydict] {
        set value [dict get $mydict $key]

comments.body: i would like to better document the inputs and output (scale / units or alike) of that function, so the reader doesn't need to read it or follow the link.
